questions.question: If a massless rope passes over an ideal pulley, how does the tension on one side compare to the tension on the other?
options: The tension is greater on the side with the moving mass.
The tension is the same on both sides.
The tension is zero at the point of contact with the pulley.
The tension is doubled on the side being pulled down.
questions.explanation: Ideal pulley is frictionless and massless, so tension is transmitted undiminished; same on both sides.

questions.question: According to the 'Rope Length Constraint,' if two objects are connected by a single inextensible rope over a pulley, they must have:
questions.explanation: Rope length constant means displacements are equal, so acceleration magnitudes are equal.

questions.question: What happens to the tension in a vertical rope if the object it is supporting begins to accelerate downward?
options: The tension becomes greater than the weight.
The tension becomes less than the weight.
The tension remains equal to the weight.
questions.explanation: $mg - T = ma$ ⇒ $T = mg - ma$, which is less than $mg$.

questions.question: A $6 \text{ kg}$ block on a frictionless horizontal table is connected to a $4 \text{ kg}$ hanging mass. What is the acceleration? (Use $g = 10\text{ m/s}^2$)
A $10 \text{ kg}$ mass is being lifted upward by a rope with an acceleration of $2 \text{ m/s}^2$. What is the tension? (Use $g = 10\text{ m/s}^2$)
A $10 \text{ kg}$ mass is on a rough table ($\mu_k = 0.2$) and is connected to a $10 \text{ kg}$ hanging mass. What is the acceleration? (Use $g = 10\text{ m/s}^2$)
A hand pulls a rope with $100 \text{ N}$ of force. This rope passes through a movable pulley supporting a $15 \text{ kg}$ load. What is the net upward force on the load? (Use $g = 10\text{ m/s}^2$)
questions.explanation: Movable pulley multiplies force: two rope segments support load, so upward force = $2 \times 100 = 200\text{ N}$.

questions.question: A 30 kg mass rests on a table and is connected by a rope over a pulley to a 10 kg mass hanging vertically. The coefficient of friction ($\mu$) is 0.4. Determine the acceleration of the system. (Use $g = 10\text{ m/s}^2$)
questions.explanation: $f_k = \mu m_1g = 0.4 \times 30 \times 10 = 120\text{ N}$. Hanging weight $= 100\text{ N}$ < $f_k$, so system doesn't move: $a = 0$.

questions.question: A 15 kg industrial motor sits on a horizontal workbench and is linked via a light cable to a 10 kg counterweight that hangs freely over a frictionless pulley at the edge of the bench. The coefficient of kinetic friction ($\mu_k$) between the motor and the workbench surface is 0.3. When the system is released from rest, calculate the magnitude of the acceleration for the connected masses. (Use $g = 9.8\text{ m/s}^2$)

Two weights, $M_A = 4.0\text{ kg}$ and $M_B = 6.0\text{ kg}$, are connected by a light, inextensible string draped over a frictionless, massless pulley in a standard Atwood machine configuration. After the system is released from rest, calculate the tension ($T$) in the string while the weights are in motion. (Use $g = 9.8\text{ m/s}^2$)
